description:
This world demonstrates the use of various functions to
add or remove various artefacts, 
to see if a certain type of artefact is present
at a given location, and to find out which artefacts
are present at a given location.

It is also intended to be used in some automated tests.

The content of the "Pre" editor is the following:

INSERT_PRE
pre:
# Background tiles are the simplest: there
# can only be one at a given location

assert not RUR.is_background_tile("water", 2, 1)
RUR.add_background_tile("water", 2, 1)
assert RUR.is_background_tile("water", 2, 1)
assert "water" == RUR.get_background_tile(2, 1)
#--------
# Note: get_background_tile is singular as there can be only
# one at a given location
#---------

RUR.add_background_tile("grass", 2, 1)
# grass replaced water
assert RUR.is_background_tile("grass", 2, 1)
assert not RUR.is_background_tile("water", 2, 1)

#-------------------------------------------
# Decorative objects; there can be more than
# one at a given location.

assert not RUR.is_decorative_object("tulip", 3, 1)
RUR.add_decorative_object("tulip", 3, 1)
assert RUR.is_decorative_object("tulip", 3, 1)

RUR.add_decorative_object("carrot", 3, 1)
# Both decorative objects are now present
assert RUR.is_decorative_object("tulip", 3, 1)
assert RUR.is_decorative_object("carrot", 3, 1)

# note the plural form of get_decorative_objects
assert ["tulip", "carrot"] == RUR.get_decorative_objects(3, 1)
RUR.remove_decorative_object("carrot", 3, 1)
assert ["tulip"] == RUR.get_decorative_objects(3, 1)

# Decorative objects are drawn on top of background tiles
RUR.add_decorative_object("daisy", 2, 1)

#-----------------------------------------------
# Obstacles follow the same rules as decorative objects

assert not RUR.is_obstacle("fence_left", 4, 1)
RUR.add_obstacle("fence_left", 4, 1)
assert RUR.is_obstacle("fence_left", 4, 1)

RUR.add_obstacle("fire", 4, 1) # animated
# Both obstacles are now present
assert RUR.is_obstacle("fence_left", 4, 1)
assert RUR.is_obstacle("fire", 4, 1)
assert ["fence_left", "fire"] == RUR.get_obstacles(4, 1)

RUR.remove_obstacle("fence_left", 4, 1)
assert ["fire"] == RUR.get_obstacles(4, 1)

# Obstacles are drawn on top of decorative objects
RUR.add_decorative_object("fence_vertical", 2, 1)

#-----------------------------------------------
# Bridges: there can be only one at a given location -

# We can use anything as a bridge
assert not RUR.is_bridge("fence_double", 5, 1)
RUR.add_bridge("fence_double", 5, 1)
assert RUR.is_bridge("fence_double", 5, 1)
assert "fence_double" == RUR.get_bridge(5, 1) # bridge: singular

# If we attempt to add a second bridge at a given
# location, an error is raised ...

exception_raised = False
try:
    RUR.add_bridge("apple", 5, 1)
except ReeborgError:
    exception_raised = True
assert exception_raised

# ... unless we are evaluating code from the
# Onload editor, which we can simulate here
RUR.state.evaluating_onload = True
RUR.add_bridge("apple", 5, 1)
assert "apple" == RUR.get_bridge(5, 1)
RUR.state.evaluating_onload = False

RUR.remove_bridge("apple", 5, 1)
RUR.add_bridge("bridge", 5, 1)
assert "bridge" == RUR.get_bridge(5, 1)

# Bridges are drawn on top of background tiles
# but below everything else
RUR.add_bridge("bridge", 2, 1)

#-----------------------------------------------
# Objects have the most options; here we do not
# include "goals" but show most other options.

assert not RUR.get_objects(6, 1) # Javascript null
assert not RUR.is_object("token", 6, 1)

RUR.add_object("token", 6, 1)
assert RUR.is_object("token", 6, 1)
assert not RUR.is_object("daisy", 6, 1)

RUR.add_object("daisy", 6, 1)
assert RUR.is_object("token", 6, 1)
assert RUR.is_object("daisy", 6, 1)

RUR.add_object("token", 6, 1)
assert dict(RUR.get_objects(6, 1)) == {"daisy": 1, 
                                       "token": 2}

RUR.add_object("token", 6, 1, {"number":10})
assert dict(RUR.get_objects(6, 1)) == {"daisy": 1, 
                                       "token": 12}

RUR.remove_object("token", 6, 1)
assert dict(RUR.get_objects(6, 1)) == {"daisy": 1, 
                                       "token": 11}

RUR.remove_object("token", 6, 1, {"number": 5})
assert dict(RUR.get_objects(6, 1)) == {"daisy": 1, 
                                       "token": 6}

RUR.remove_object("token", 6, 1, {"all": True})
assert dict(RUR.get_objects(6, 1)) == {"daisy": 1}

# objects are drawn on top of obstacles and everything
# else mentioned above
RUR.add_object("token", 2, 1)

#-----------------------------------------------
# Pushable: there can be only one at a given location 

# We can use anything as a pushable
assert not RUR.is_pushable("apple", 7, 1)
RUR.add_pushable("apple", 7, 1)
assert RUR.is_pushable("apple", 7, 1)
assert "apple" == RUR.get_pushable(7, 1) # pushable: singular

# If we attempt to add a second pushable at a given
# location, an exception is raised

exception_raised = False
try:
    RUR.add_pushable("box", 7, 1)
except ReeborgError:
    exception_raised = True

assert exception_raised

RUR.remove_pushable("apple", 7, 1)
RUR.add_pushable("box", 7, 1)
assert "box" == RUR.get_pushable(7, 1)

# Pushables are drawn on top of everything else.
RUR.add_obstacle("water", 10, 1)
RUR.add_pushable("token", 10, 1)
